DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Facility has been sold. Anchor Warehouse no longer operates this facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Anchor Warehouse Porterville has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Anchor Warehouse Porterville, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Anchor Warehouse Porterville has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                | Process Chemical              | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration         Anhydrous Ammonia               21,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the

PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Anchor Warehouse (Porterville) is a commercial cold storage for various fruit and vegetable products.  The facility has an ammonia system that provides refrigeration capacity to fifteen (15) cold rooms equipped with evaporator coils for cooling product.  Five (5) rooms are designated as "precooling" rooms, while ten (10) others are cold storage rooms.  



The system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receivers is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into a low pressure accumulator vessel mounted behind the bunker wall.  Low temperature liquid circulates by thermal convection through the evaporator coils located behind bunker walls in the cold rooms.  Low pressure and temperature gas collects in the accumulator vessel, and passes through a pressure regulator into a suction line.  The suction line returns the vapor to the main suction accumulators located in the engine room, which separates any residual liquid from the gas.  The gas is piped to screw compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressor is sent to a water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receivers. Liquid separated from the suction return gas in the main suction accumulator drains into liquid transfer vessels.  Operation of a float switch activated solenoid valve raises the pressure in the liquid transfer vessels to the point the liquid can be drained into the high pressure receiv

ers.



The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.  



The ammonia system at this facility consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected.  Therefore, the system 

is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Anchor Warehouse Porterville has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Anchor Warehouse Porterville facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 17,400 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active logbook of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These c

ontractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Anchor Warehouse Porterville has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Anchor Warehouse Porterville's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Anchor Warehouse Porterville has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Anchor Warehouse Porterville continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Anchor Warehouse Porterville's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Anchor Warehouse Porterville's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Anchor Warehouse Porterville has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed,

the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Anchor Warehouse Porterville has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Anchor Warehouse Porterville now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Anchor Warehouse Porterville employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Anchor Warehouse Porterville will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
